Comment: An advance directive can only be used if a competent adult has ordered it. That eliminates the use of such agreements where children are concerned.

In the event that I'm diagnosed with dementia AND I'm unable to function without help in certain specific areas, I would like to take advantage of a doctor assisted death. I trust my 2 children to know when that time has come.
I do not want to live if I cannot feed myself, bathe myself,communicate with others & do not recognize those I love.
I've heard that it's possible to live for several years with dementia but eventually, a decent life becomes impossible.

Comment: Hi, CAE - I'm going to respectfully disagree with you on this one. Francis continues to use the same language of sin, mercy, and salvation that effectively trivializes our relationships with God and one another. Granted, he is an advocate for mercy, but that mercy is for people who have made mistakes anyone could make, for people who have been victimized by violent spouses, and so on. Mistakes aren't sins and we don't need salvation from them, but we keep mumbling about sin and salvation as if that's the only way to understand our relationship with God. 
I prefer to think that God raises up people to help us make course corrections, not to judge and condemn us if we don't get it right. I suspect Francis is inclined to think in those terms as well, but as long as he keeps speaking about us as sinners, I think he's just putting cheese on a donkey's -- well, I guess it sounds better in Italian. - Monica.

Comment: You are correct about the effect of corporate consolidation on journalism, but you seemingly misunderstand the relationship between government and the press. Yes, the government produces a lot of press releases, and it's policy initiatives and interactions with other parties and stakeholders are covered by the press. That's as it should be: the press obviously must inform the public about what the government is doing. To say that that amounts to the press relying "on government sources to provide it with the news it sells" seems kind of nutty. Are you suggesting that a free and uncorrupted press should refuse to report on government? Moreover, government does not own the airwaves. The public does. The air waves are regulated by the CRTC, which manages stakeholders in the public interest.

So damn the brakes, full speed ahead! GO BRONCOS!

Comment: This isn't about 'cars', it's about oil demand, which the IEA forecasts to grow at about 1/2 million barrels per year to about 2040.  Demand for oil to power passenger cars, for example, may drop, other sectors will offset this fall.   To quote the EIA, "“The difficulty of finding alternatives to oil in  freight, aviation and petrochemicals means that, up to 2040, the growth in these three sectors alone is greater than the growth in global oil demand,” the IEA said in its annual World Energy Outlook."

Infrastructure requires forecasting, with risk and reliance on whatever data can be fed into its models. If we took a 'do nothing' approach nobody would build anything ever.  Why has the USA built > 10,000 miles of pipe since 2008? They are ramping up their LNG industry.  They are ramping up oil exports. Why? Demand... for the long term, that's why.

EV's make little sense if the electricity to power them comes from coal.  We are simply moving the GHG problem around, not fixing it.

Comment: Don't be so sure that Boeing gets a black eye from this deal. They may be playing 3D chess here.
Their real long term concern is uncontrolled state subsidized players, China's COMAC and Russia's UAC, who have introduced a 737/A320 competitor. By contrast Airbus is a known manageable competitor subject to some constraints through international trade bodies.
Airbus has no more incentive than Boeing at letting COMAC and UAC get their hands on state of the art technology in the C-series. Airbus already has the A320 at the upper end of the commuter aircraft market, they won't let the C-series move upmarket. If the Chinese or Russians had gotten it, they would have moved upmarket selling these versions at real fire sale prices.
Finally, Boeing never had interest in the low margin lower end of the commuter market. They can let Airbus duke it out with their partner Embraer. Leaving Boeing to focus on the much higher margin MoM 797 program.

Comment: Calling Trump "Jacksonian" is idiotic.  Yes, Jackson was the first national politician to mobilize a non-moneyed constituency.  But when Jackson became president in 1829, he was not only a famous military hero.  He had also served in both houses of Congress and as military governor of the Florida territory.  He knew well, and was known by, all of the prominent political figures of his day.  And, in office, Jackson displayed a deep grasp of the Constitution and a determination to defend it against the growing possibility of secession.

None of this, of course, is true of Trump, who never served in the armed forces, never served in (or even ran for) public office, and apparently doesn't even pay income taxes.  Trump has never shown the slightest interest in the Constitution.  He has always been a political groupie, hanging around conventions for whatever scraps of attention he could pick up and engaging in scams like the Birther Lie.  He is no more like Jackson than Sarah Palin is.

Comment: Thanks for the reference.  It seems like the distinction banished was between the protection afforded the quickened, vs un-quickened, fetus's. A moral distinction. One may find support in that, for the view that the soul comes at conception, but it falls well short of making that assertion. It's an argument from moral caution, rather than certainty.

From the EPE:
"Pope Pius IX challenged the canonical tradition about the beginning of ensouled life set by Pope Gregory XIV in 1591. He believed that while it may not be known when ensoulment occurs, there was the possibility that it happens at conception. Believing it was morally safer to follow this conclusion, he thought all life should be protected from the start of conception. " 

I know it's hard to believe, but one line of the Church's argument rests, in significant part, on moral caution, rather than material certainty. Another rests on equivalence -- that to kill the thing at point A is morally the same as doing so at point C or Z

Comment: What is seemingly rarely addressed is how "Medicare for all" will be funded, answered honestly and straight forward. Currently income taxes fund the largest portion of Medicare, then payroll taxes and finally premiums.

"Medicare is funded primarily from three sources: general revenues(41%), payroll taxes(38%), and beneficiary premiums(13%)." http://www.kff.org/medicare/fact-sheet/medicare-spending-and-financing-fact-sheet/

The federal government already controls about 67% of the US healthcare system via Medicare, Medicaid, VA. About 109 million Americans are covered by Medicare, Medicaid and VA so about another 216 million would need to be enrolled in "Medicare of all." How will "Medicare for all" be funded with the additional 216 million beneficiaries? Being naive I would like to see that question answered honestly and openly.

BTW, I believe with the US government already controlling 67% of national healthcare, single-payer ultimately is the only workable solution.

Comment: So you are now the judge of every divorce and annulment that takes place in the U.S.---never mind the rest of the world?  ALL people don't just 'move on.' All he had to do was to give his wife a writ---and she was history.  If her father was still alive--she could ask to come home---but he didn't have to admit her.  And if he did, he could beat her for bringing shame to the family name.  Most women had to resort to prostitution to survive.  Jesus was very much aware of this.

Comment: The issue before the Supreme Court is not whether individual students will be accepted by the LSUC - it's whether TWU's possible future law school will be accredited, given the rules it says it will require of all students.

In fact, there is a procedure for non-accredited law schools to request that their students be assessed by the LSUC on an individual basis.  We don't know what the LSUC's answer would be because TWU has never asked.

The LSUC had a statutory duty to make sure that accredited law schools do not discriminate in their admissions policies.  This was the right decision, and the only decision they could have come to given their statutory mandate.

Comment: "four principles: freedom, fairness, responsibility and respect."

Agreed.

Canada is free to establish a system to provide its citizens with a stable, secure supply of quality food at an affordable price.

Fairness: the price that dairy farmers receive is determined by a formula that is based on an averaged cost of production. Farmers in the non-supply managed sectors are subject to the uncontrolled ups & downs of production volumes which of course affect farm-gate prices. Consequently, most Canadian farmers' income has to be supplemented by off-farm jobs.  

Responsibility: food security should matter to Canadians. Eventually something will interfere with our globalized, import-dependent, just-in-time food supply chain: a grain or livestock infestation, an oil supply/transportation crisis, a climate-induced crop failure, etc.  It is prudent for every nation to more or less feed its population.

Respect: our hard-working farmers should be respected and supported by the other 98%.

Comment: "This guaranteed them a market after patents expired because the generic producers would see no advantage to make a generic". 

Pharmaceutical companies, even the ones that normally produce generics, only produce the generics that return the best profit.  So if there are two generics in the same therapeutic space, companies will drop the cheaper one and produce the more expensive. This morning every pharmacy in Ontario will have a list of medications that are on back order or unavailable. They will all have one thing in common - they are cheap.

The solution is for the Federal government to set up a crown corporation, non-profit, with a mandate to poduce common, cheap, proven generic medications that have been abandoned by the drug companies. It would provide jobs and could become a good source of cheap medications to the developing world, and an alternative to expensive drugs in hospitals and clinics.

Comment: "Trudeau isn't doing so poorly"

There's lots of angles to attack this one, but one example will suffice: marijuana legalization.  

The LPC 'legalized marijuana' by downloading the responsibility for enforcement, policy and standards to the provinces, but nonsensically retained federal criminal legislation for sale to minors, introducing a guaranteed conflict between the provincial right to set age of majority and federal enforcement of that law.  Are we really going to get into the business of arresting people and putting them in FEDERAL prison for selling to an 18 year old in Ontario, when that 18 year old can cross over into Quebec and buy it perfectly legally?  It's what already happens with alcohol, but we're talking fines at the provincial level for alcohol, not felony convictions like we would with pot.

It's juvenile legislation that got rushed so the feds had a chance of getting it out in the public's eyes by 420. It's that kind of 'optics first' thinking that's so idiotic.

Comment: But the point wasn't about holding business to account. It was about impact. As it happened Oracle was in the end one of the last states in America to get its exchange up. To great detriment of the people. And that was not critical infrastructure.

Forget accountability. Its about risk/reward analysis. The risk if a company does this with something like water is that millions die. Such a risk requires a truly massive reward to even be considered. So where is this reward? What benefit can privatization offer that's so significant it is worth risking millions of lives for?

You don't have competition. You don't have market forces. More than a few water privatization projects have been disasters as companies were derelict in their duties and caused great environmental and social harm. So the risk is real. Where is the massive guarantees benefit to offset that risk?

Comment: Hah, while I had a good laugh, and I'm sure plenty of ex-Californians suffer from this kind of prejudice, I legitimately am appalled after trying Tacos Chukis and being told it was the best taco in town :) I went in 100% expecting to have tacos as good as the ones back home. I didn't have anything fancy in the Bay Area, just a couple of local taco trucks in Mountain View (Cheztakos and Mamacitas), and the tacos were amazing with flavorful, warm, tortillas, and juicy/crispy meat that was freshly grilled right in front of you. Not only does Chukis only have like 3 meat options, but the Asada which I tried was dry, flavorless, and the tortillas were barely warm and tasted like chalk. Much like the tacos I had driving through Oregon, which I had hoped was just a fluke.

I've had so many fantastic food experience since arriving in Seattle (Paseo? Flying Apron? Tutta Bella? Din Tai Fung?) but two things are irrevocably true -- tacos here are not as good, and Dick's is nothing like In-N-Out.

Comment: This is an interesting story that proves that sometimes people just don't like living next to a religious institution, even when it is an institution that represents their own religion:

http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/despite-residents-opposition-cote-st-luc-council-approves-synagogue

Cote St Luc is a suburb of Montreal whose population is close to 60% jewish. After the city council approved a zoning change to allow construction of a new synagogue, the residents acquired the necessary number of signatures required to call for a referendum to block it, after already having submitted a 70 signature petition to ask that the project be halted.

http://www.cjnews.com/news/canada/proposed-new-shul-divides-largely-jewish-cote-st-luc

The mayor, understanding that the "no synagogue in my backyard" side would win the referendum, has decided to rescind permission to build a synagogue in that location and is helping the synagogue to find another location.

Comment: What saddens me about college football is that with a little bit of restraint legislated from the NCAA, many more programs could be like LSU. Comment: They basically just get added in chronological order. Back in the 1970s and 1980s, people generally just said "lesbian and gay", or "L/G". Bisexuals got added on in the early 1990s -- "lesbian, gay or bisexual", or "LGB" -- and then the T for transgender started showing up in the late 1990s and early 2000s as transgender people started becoming more visible. And much more recently, as more and more people started identifying as "queer", the Q was tacked on at the end. Basically, the letters don't get rearranged; each new letter just gets added on to the end of whatever the acronym was before.

Comment: Missing in this article is the reason for...the cause of...what appears to be a rather sudden affliction of gastrointestinal disturbance among your climbing partners. Did the afflicted personnel drink from some common source? Or patronize the same pre-climb food dispensary? Crucial information since it might indicate just how quickly these maladies might strike after...what? Drinking the wrong water? I've been drinking the water for 45 years. I've seen the little animal turds bounce along the bottom while drinking. Drank from below beaver dams. Presume I'm carrying the giardia. I've drank from 4-wheeler tracks. Swamp water...which tastes worse when boiled...so I don't. Lake waters with birds on them make me queasy. The best water comes right out of cracks in the rock. Mountain streams are good.However, I will drink from no water where humans are around...or upstream. On popular climbs like April Bowl at Hatcher Pass I carry two liters of water. Don't filter or boil...but am careful.

Comment: I can verify your thesis unequivocally.  (i.e. driving customers away)

I currently REFUSE to fly, unless it is absolutely, absolutely necessary 
(i.e. having to get to a funeral on unexpected death of a grandparent)

If I do fly, then I fly business class whenever possible... yes I pay for the upgrade
Because I fly so infrequently, this option (while expensive) is within budget

Flying is NOT fun... a 5 hour flight to Vancouver is the equivalent of being jammed onto a stinky, over-stuffed cattle car for a 5 hour train ride from Toronto to Montreal.   For me, it ruins the entire trip to be left with a feeling of being treated worse than animals on the way to slaughter.

So... we travel less, and when we do travel, it tends to be by auto, to locations within a day or so drive from the city - much more pleasant, we can bring the luggage we choose to bring, and we can leave and arrive on our own time schedule.

I'm sure we're not the only ones who have chosen to turn away from air travel.

Comment: Marbury vs. Madison gives the courts the power to examine the legality of actions by the president, which I have no problem with. It does not give them the power to remake the Constitution or the laws enacted by the Congress; they can only enforce them. This court allowed a plaintiff who had no standing to bring an action; held the plaintiff, who could show no actual damages—only hypothetical ones and claimed hurt "feelings" about Mr. Trump's order—could limit the legal power of the president; and is thus allowing non-Americans (who were not even party to the suit) to have Constitutional rights when they have precisely none. If the higher courts do not overturn this nonsense, where does it stop? Are we to allow anyone from anywhere who applies for a Visa to enter our country unabated? If the President orders a military strike against an enemy abroad, can the court put a hold on that?

Your argument has no legal basis, Gary, and has ramifications you seem not to have thought through.

"Anyone, you see, can pass a tax cut that expires after 10 years. Comment: Who are the opponents of this program? When did it become a negative for young people to work hard for what they want? Yes, the housing situation in some areas might need some oversight or improvements, but maybe not. These are adults for the most part, making choices every day about how to exploit the system and make the most money they can in a short time period. 

In Petersburg, the J-1 students were awesome! We would hold soccer tournaments and cook-outs several times a summer for them and the spirit of sportsmanship and just good energy from those kids was palpable most times. Yes, they were exhausted from working really long shifts on the slime line, but they were so happy to be raking in the  dough. One student from Poland told me he wouldn't have to work at all the last two years of college because he had made so much in the one year he was a J-1.

It was years ago, but I myself worked three jobs to get through college. It was a good thing, not something to be complained about.

Comment: Ways to foster innovation in Canada:

1.  Protect the institutions of democracy and the rule of law that allow innovation to flourish.  Permitting the fed. gov't to be captured by the oil industry for a decade  killed innovation in Canada: research institutions were closed or defunded, scientists were gagged and intimidated; the over-valued petro-Looney killed manufacturers.

Electoral reform to strengthen democracy by getting rid of FPP to prevent a repeat of that disaster should be the top priority of any government interested in promoting innovation.

2.  Get rid of tax incentives and subsidies that make it more attractive to dig things out of the ground than to engage in innovation, e.g., put a big price on carbon.

3.  Make our cities places where creative people want to live - that means dealing with decaying infrastructure built in the 50's and 60's, and it means building effective public transit like they have in Europe.

4.  Provide a more rounded basic education to everyone.

Comment: (2)   Autocrats like Erdogan love the rule of law even more than do liberal democrats, because it reinforces and strengthens the political construct. It's an easy sell too, promising  security at the expense of freedom. But as Turkey proves, the two things aren't connected. Seeking security that way is futile. Freedom combined with security is only available to those who emphasize the social contract over the political construct. At it's most fundamental codified level, in Canada the social contract is the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

"Order and security are the very foundation of citizens’ ability to enjoy genuine democratic freedoms." By now you can see why this statement is false. The foundation of democratic freedom is the social contract, not the political construct. The political construct can all too easily swing in the direction of oppression. That's why civil libertarians are quick to speak out when the government turns in that direction even slightly.

Comment: The Minnedosa ethanol  plant is one of the largest emitters of greenhouse gas in Manitoba. The article suggests that we should increase the amount of ethanol currently mandated as an environmental gasoline additive. 

A fatal Lac Magantic type rail tanker fire in the US was what started the implementation of the new design for a new type of rail tanker. The train's cargo was ethanol. Lets use Canadian rail to haul more ethanol to fuel blending plants. (Pipelines can no longer be built in Canada.)

I am not aware of any bio-diesel produced in Canada that will can be used in a diesel engine in cold weather. A company in Finland has built two specialized refineries that make a winter grade additive to make biodiesel. They typically use palm oil as the raw ingredient. 

BC was the first Canadian province to mandate the reduction of carbon in motor fuels. They quickly backed off their plan when they discovered that it doesn't work on a Canadian winter.

Comment: According to the Oregon basic speed law, if one drives off the roadway then one is driving too fast for conditions. Therefore,  excessive speed must be a factor in this crash. The driver's speed may have been in line with what is safe for those conditions for some other driver or for her under other conditions, but she was unable to control her vehicle at that speed under those conditions and was thus speeding. 

I know no one wants to be blamed for the death of a child and it's much easier to blame the lack of guard rails, but when one fails to drive with an adequate margin for safety it puts this sort of tragic outcome in play. It's important for the community to learn the right lesson here. It's not that deadly crashes are inevitable or that we need to make everything fool-proof. It's that we all need to slow down and pay more attention when we are driving, even on roads that we have driven thousands of times.

Comment: In the 3rd grade in the late 1950's in a small Catholic school I was taught that "only in the Catholic Church could one be saved". RE: "Of all points of faith, the being of a God is, to my own apprehension, encompassed with most difficulty, and yet borne in upon our minds with most power."   Comprehending God is like discerning the interior of a giant crystal through our own private facet, we see the sharp reflection of our reality  blended with an opaque internal reality.  Every interpretation is necessarily different and the discerner deserves our respect, not judgement which is reserved for the Owner of the crystal.

Comment: So.
For the point in time count, of a single day, it is fairly consistent at about 5,000 homeless.  But throughout a year, people become homeless, and then get things fixed back up. some people are homeless a few days, a few weeks, or a few months. But annually, there are roughly 15,000 people that end up homeless at some point.

Now, the problem with both counts, is that you can only count people you can find or that seek help. There are MANY homeless that do not ask for any help at all, among them the hidden homeless. unfortunately they are not counted since they do not interact with any agencies. 
Also, only agencies that receive state, city or federal money are required to put data into the states HMIS system. So private agencies that do not receive grant money are not required to report their data. Like Churches. Some churches run their services strictly on donations, The people getting help may not be getting help from any other agency, and end up not being counted.

Comment: Unfortunately it's not that simple. While FDA does allow such blood to be donated, donors must pass the standard screening criteria and not all donors will qualify. Donors with hemochromatosis often must be screened by a physician at time of donation. There are additional labeling requirements for blood donated from hemochromatosis patients which add increased costs and extra steps to the manufacturing process. These additional requirements and costs make the provision of hemochromatosis donor blood too expensive for many facilities. Blood Bank of AK is not alone in this, the Red Cross is one of the highest volume suppliers in the US and doesn't accept donations from hemochromatosis patients.
From FDA: "the blood establishment must either 1) label the collected blood with the donor's disorder and have a physician examine the donor on the day of donation if less than eight weeks has passed since the previous donation, or 2) apply for the variances."

Comment: "[T]he Academy of Construction and Engineering has a disproportionately higher population of students who are male (75%) [&] in poverty." How is this the result of "unintentionally created segregation & inequity"? This is a choice district -- if kids who choose ACE tend to be male & poor, that is a reflection of our society as a whole, not a "problem with the SLC system."

As for ACE having a higher student population receiving special education services & disciplinary referrals, earning D/F grades, not attending post-secondary educational institutions, scoring poorly on state exams & being absent from school at a higher rate -- these are obviously the result of ACE leadership. Since the other 3 SLCs in the report did NOT have these issues it's clearly not a "problem with the SLC system."

Yet it was the ACE principal that was chosen to head all 4 SLCs this year. He won't be continuing but it does make one wonder why the district chose the leader of the failing school to lead all four.

Comment: Take a look at these graphs, from the Oregon Office of Economic Analysis:  
https://oregoneconomicanalysis.com/2016/03/30/oregon-job-polarization-update-2015/  

The state is calling this job polarization.  Middle wage jobs have disappeared and been replaced by low wage jobs (maybe).  There are a number of new higher wage jobs, but we also have new people (some of them working people) moving into the area again.   Housing and rent costs have shot way up, so no wonder it is harder to make ends meet:  harder to find a decent paying job and the cost of living has gone up.    

These graphs show where the jobs are clustering:  at the top, and the bottom.  The shape of the curve says much more than a simplistic "median" wage does.  

Sue

Comment: Having recently retired form a career of sourcing in for a very large Canadian company, I have some insight into this discussion. During the past 10 years, there has been a major movement away from China in purchasing because of our duty structure. For instance, China is no longer our largest supplier of textile products - we have punitive duties on apparel and many other categories of product from China while we are already offering duty free access to a number of other countries under the UN agreements for LDCs (least developed countries). The LDCs buy almost nothing from Canada and the trade relationship is completely one sided. 
China has a very real incentive to sign a free trade agreement with Canada in order to get back some of the billions of dollars of exports which they have lost. In addition, China is our largest potential market for energy, lumber, agricultural products and minerals which are our main exports. 
The timing is good - if we can negotiate a decent deal.

Comment: At every public employer I know about personally, administrative leave is separate from vacation, sick leave, or other types of accrued paid time off.  I just called Springfield School District to clarify this is the case there as well. You can do the same and confirm the answer in only a few minutes.

The reason for this is that, as its name implies, administrative leave is based on an administrator's decision, and is not voluntary on the employee's part. In this case, Crouch has not yet been convicted of any crime and the investigation is ongoing, so punitive actions such as termination or suspension without pay would be premature. Paying an employee's salary while an investigation and prosecution (if applicable) are completed is far cheaper than settling a wrongful termination suit later, and of course no one wants an accused teacher in the classroom before the matter is resolved.

Comment: You base your reaction, your critique, on someone else's review of the play?
Now that's SAD, especially since the review is flawed.
J. Kelly Nestruck tells us that Viola and her brother Sebastian are shipwrecked, and that "she washes up alone on the coast of Illyria." That's misleading. They both wash up on Illyria but separated. Until the final Act, Sebastian is sure his sister perished, while she holds but hope for his survival. To know this is essential to any understanding of the play. They reunite only at the end of the play.
JKN says that "for some reason" Viola disguises herself as a boy so as to serve the local Duke, when actually it is for good reason: Viola identifies with the object of the Duke's affections, Olivia, since both women are in mourning. Viola would prefer to serve Olivia direct but can't get near her and so must go as an emissary.
My impression of JKN's review is that the performance does not match her expectation for a rib-tickling comedy, which the play isn't.

Comment: Light shimmering off the gold ciborium and sparkling from the crystal pitcher caught my eye, and transported me back to college days in my parish church. The afternoon Mass at 5:15 was attended by a handful of people: two or three elderly members of the parish, a teacher or two from the school. The gifts stood on a precariously fragile looking table placed between the first row of pews. But it wasn't gold or crystal. The wine was in an ordinary glass cruet, the small hosts in a rather ancient and not particularly shiny ciborium. The cloth covering the table was blazing white and starched well enough to probably support the whole building. And this little congregation of people attending, at the end of the long day, attended to the simple ritual and words of a weekday Mass--nourished after the day's journey, refreshed from our thirst, unwinding in a small and familiar company of saints (in the best sense of that word) while beyond the heavy doors the world still rumbled by.

Comment: I think in the generation that went through the statehood battle there were some who emerged who truly loved this state and its people, although in differing ways.  I think especially of Jay Hammond (who opposed statehood) and Wally Hickel (who championed it).  They were diametrically opposed politicians with drastically different visions for Alaska, but they both loved it with all their hearts and souls.  The rivalry between those two and the ways they shaped Alaska would make for a fascinating book.  Neither one of them fit anyone's mold for how a politician is supposed to think and act.  They were both Republicans, but neither of them was a party hack.  Both were highly controversial while in office and made plenty of enemies along the way (including each other), but I've come to believe that both wanted what they genuinely believed was best for Alaska and Alaskans.

Comment: "Sky high condo prices" are absolutely a supply problem.  If there was more supply, condos would be cheaper by virtue of cheaper land.  The fact that land constitutes a significant proportion of the development cost and developable land for multi-units are problematic because of municipal government approvals which can take years.  That's risk.  Then when it does get approved, development charges (which were originally a means of recovery of costs for infrastructure, and is now a cash flow tax) take their toll, along with HST.  In fact, the government take is greater than most developer profit.  The answer -- make land easier to develop, increase densities, and get used to the idea that detached homes are inefficient, ineffective means of accommodating a large population.

Comment: The problem for Metro is that its prices are already about as high as it dares to go without risking an increased exodus to other stores.  When the price tag on cooked cold roast beef in the deli department is $37.40 a kilo at Metro and only $25.90 a kilo at another grocery store not far away, customers do tend to  wonder why.   Best Before dates are regularly ignored at Metro and, in some cases, on products the consumption of which after the optimum date, could be dangerous.  It shouldn’t be the customers' job to keep track of these dates – Metro must surely have computers to do this kind of work.
It's not as if Metro is offering anything spectacular in the way of ambiance or service – it’s a very ordinary store, so why, exactly, do the prices need to be so high?   If Metro dare not raise prices to claw back higher wage costs, it won't be because of the increase to the minimum wage, it will be because Metro's prices were not competitive to begin with.

Comment: I fought the bag and the bag won.
I found the trees in my immaculate (ha!) yard all festooned with bags after a wind storm. 'I'll just reach up with a long stick and pull them down' I thought. Too high up. Just step up on a limb and reach...still too high. Try one more limb. Nope. One more..."CRACK!" Fell out of the tree, branch stabbed my leg on the way down, blood all over the place. Bags are still up there, they mock me as I enter the driveway.
I was in San Francisco soon after and got hotel snacks. The clerk asked if I wanted a bag. I had quite a few snacks and cans of pop so I said yes. She handed me a plastic bag and rang up an additional ten cents. Seemed odd but "When in Rome..." Got back to room, emptied the bag, folded it and put it in my pocket. I'm all set!
I visited Cordova a couple years ago on a job. Didn't want to go but it turned out to be just a perfect little town. It was winter, sun was shining, the harbor was so serene I was amazed. Why had I not been there before?

Comment: Well darn. Another piece of history bites it. Chair 1 was a long ride but it went all the way in one go.

Comment: It should not be my job to post such information. I have other duties and responsibilities in my life. This should be the job of professional journalists and editors who should strive for objectivity and impartiality when covering the news, and not let biases, and the perception of what their target audience may like to hear, get in the way of that job. This would go a long way to restore public confidence in the media and lead to more thoughtful and substantial discussions of the issues by people who may have different but legitimate and fact-based points of view. There is plenty of useful information out there, but in order to be well informed, people have to have the ability to conduct thorough research. Childish name calling, and refusing to take other points of view into account, or explore issues that don't confirm biases are not helpful in advancing any intelligent conversation, but perhaps the real point of such tactics is shutting down conversations rather than promoting them.

Comment: Doesn't need to be anywhere near as dense as Manhattan for transit and walking to be serious modes of transportation. The entire city of Denver was once well served by streetcars. 

No idea what the rest of that babbling was about. Yes, in denser areas transit works well, in the suburbs where it's not dense, it doesn't. That's what I'm saying.

The downtown/airport comment makes no sense either. Much of our current transit routes focus on to/from downtown, so what? They are focused on downtown now partly because that is one of the few areas where you can get off a bus and walk to your destination. Much of the rest of the metro area is too sparse. Which is exactly my point. If we add more people within our already developed area we can get up to a density of people and places where transit will become a much more useful option. Transit routes would then be adjusted for new travel patterns.

Or we can keep going broke building highways to the exurbs.

Comment: How many times have you seen the following:  One transport pulling out to pass another and taking the next 10 minutes and miles of highway to finally get past.   All this and 1/2 hour later the truck which passed is 15 - 30 seconds ahead of the slower truck.    It's just not worth it.

Trucks should be in a restricted lane, and passing should be prohibited, except in designated areas.

Concurrent with this should be driver education about lane discipline and yielding (instead of blocking) when a car comes up from behind.    It is not up to drivers to enforce the speed limit.    So if a car is tailgating - just move over and let him/her pass.    Don't be a stubborn jerk and block traffic, which should be ticketable offence.     That will help traffic flow, and if the tailgater is really speeding (or weaving in and out) leave it up to the police to catch them.

Comment: Both of these lines run through fairly low density areas, it will take time for development to follow them which will create ridership. 
It would make more sense to build along already busy transit routes, like what's being done with Colfax BRT. Demand is already there, more transit capacity is needed now, no waiting for development necessary. 
I understand it's easier to build rail along existing rail lines or highways, but that's not always where the people are.
Of course, when you try to build where the people are, you get all kinds of complaints about transit taking space away from drivers. 
Still, I'd rather deal with those complaints and build transit lines that go where people really need them than build where it's easy and have no riders.

Comment: The facts, however, are rather different. Toronto (and Vancouver) are near the bottom of Canadian cities for median household income (http://www.statcan.gc.ca/tables-tableaux/sum-som/l01/cst01/famil107a-eng.htm) while at the top of Canadian cities for income inequality, measured by Gini coefficient ((https://censusmapper.ca/maps/165). In other words, the reality is considerably less income per capita than enjoyed by residents of other Canadian cities, less evenly distributed.  Worse, the high cost of housing means considerably less disposable income than residents of other cities, i.e. less money for the arts, sports, and other activities that make for a good life.  There isn't much point in having lots of things to do if you don't have the money to do any of them.

Comment: After serving for the past 6 months on the committee empowered to investigate this issue and write the proposed charter revisions and ballot question, and interviewing managers and mayors and looking at numerous governance histories of communities all over the USA, we came to the conclusion that Maui County would be better served with a professional manager with administrative training and skills, who is separated from the political process and subject to accountability. 

There would, for the first time, be annual evaluations of the effectiveness of the County Administration as a whole, and each Department and Director. This is closer to the way successful businesses, the military and over 60% of US municipalities function.

The Maui County Council will meet on Monday, June 27th under the Policy and Intergovernmental Affairs Committee to discuss whether the voters of Maui will have the opportunity to decide this issue, or whether the Council Members will deny the voters this choice.

Comment: Smokes are taxed at a high rate for purposes of revenue and dissuasion. 
Street addicts, with their myriad health and property crime issues, are enormously expensive to society -- one study suggested close to 50K/year for the average Vancouver street addict. 
Meanwhile, the drugs in question are exceedingly _inexpensive_ to manufacture in a pharmaceutical setting -- less than 10% of the street price.
Governments could charge a nominal fee to cover production and distribution and _still_ be cheaper than the street cost.
Even if they made the drugs free, the reduction in associated street addiction costs would probably make up for most of that expense.
Either way, there'd be no point in making the drugs _more expensive_ than the street equivalents ..

Comment: For me, the main reason is not so much attitude's like Museveni's (determined investors always get through) but rather the population explosion.  From seven million to 37 million in 55 years, think about it.

Whether you are thinking of opening a mine or a blast furnace, the idea of doing so in a place where there are masses of dissatisfied people is not attractive.
Peru has had a significantly smaller population growth, three times over roughly the same period, and not five, and the growth rate is falling, not accelerating.  People are still poor compared to many other places, but they are less poor than before and are optimistic.  It is where I would put a mine if I had a choice.

Comment: the primary cause of crisis was Frank and Dodd's push to reduce mortgage buying standards at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, who provide liquidity to mortgagees by buying the loans they (the mortgagees) make to the public. Before Frank and Dodd were able to pass legislation weakening Fannie and Freddie's buying standards, all mortgages purchased off the primary market by these two Government Sponsored Enterprises adhered to Federal Housing Administration standards, i.e. they were "prime" loans. But Frank, Dodd, and their cohorts "rolled the dice" in regards to subprime lending, and, in effect, drowned Fannie and Freddie with junk mortgage paper. In turn, Fannie and Freddie sold the junk loans to institutional investors, who happily bought them with cheap capital provided by the Fed. Attaching trillions of dollars of derivatives to the junk they bought, these investors (particularly the Big Banks) created a bona fide financial crisis.

Comment: The FTA projects rail to cost between $8 and 10.8 billion. At $ 8 billion the FTA's $1.5 B is 19% of the cost, at $10.8 B its 13 %.  This cost does not include the extensions to West Kapolei and UH-Manoa, estimated in 2012 to cost $ 2.5 Billion and $1. 4 B respectively (total cost of $3.9 billion.). The impact on traffic congestion?  According to the City's EIS, traffic will grow by 23% in 2030, with rail traffic will grow by 21% plus, a "reduction" of roughly only 1.4%. Former DTS director Wayne Yoshioka conceded that "traffic congestion with rail in 2030 will be worse than it is without rail today".  In its ROD, FTA admits traffic congestion will not be reduced but that rail is needed as an alternative for those who do not own cars. A According to the 2003 EIS, the preferred alternative was bus rapid transit, not light rail at grade nor elevated rail which it dismissed as too costly and unsightly.  In 2004 Mufi decided to build the "too costly and unsightly" elevated heavy rail.

Comment: Energy used in LNG liquefaction and transport equal ~20% of the energy content of the shipped LNG itself. Fugitive methane leaks from wellhead to end user add substantially to the GHG footprint of this energy source, since CH4 has ~30 times the global warming potential of an equivalent volume of CO2, averaged over 100 years from its emission.

Natural gas can be burned cleaner and more efficiently than coal, but CH4 and CO2 are greenhouse gases and there is no escaping that fundamental fact.

Comment: Whoever introduced that vile bird vetch into Alaska should be hung, drawn and quartered!  Talk about invasive!  I don't think I have seen any more ecologically damaging plant in Alaska to match it, including dandelions.  At least most invasive plant species in Alaska seem to stick to disturbed soil such as roadsides and lawns, but not this nasty plant --- I have been seeing vast swathes of it in relatively open woodlands as well, particularly in and around the area near the Palmer Agricultural Experimental Station on Trunk Road where it was presumably first introduced.  I've seen it climbing up and pulling down wild rose and mooseberry plants, and I shudder to think what our woods and roadsides are going to look like in another ten or twenty years if this bird vetch cannot be controlled (which it almost certainly cannot be at this point).

Comment: If you extend your oil change intervals to 25,000 km and abuse your engine beyond belief by only driving short distances in cold weather you might shorten the engine life enough to have a detectable failure before the car dies of old age.  Otherwise, the rest of the car will die long before the engine.  Modern engines with modern oil are getting oil changes far too often.  If stretch one oil change, in this case by 10%, the odds of doing any detectable harm to the engine are zero.  If you only ever do every second recommended change, your engine will still outlast the car.  Oil changes are only for the benefit of the next owner in any event.  My truck has 410,000 hard km on it, and as you can probably guess - not maintained to any kind of a schedule, and still has never had to have a litre of oil added between changes.  Its now been overheated twice due to a radiator incident and still shows no signs of any damage or wear or drivability.

Comment: President Trump is not 'baiting' Un, rather, as I said, he is speaking in terms that Un and his generals can understand.

I am dismayed that you interpreted what I said about the safety of nuclear weapons is me thinking of myself as and authority. I am not. I am however, a degreed, experienced engineer with some knowledge of how nuclear weapons are constructed. The incidents I refer to demonstrate incidents where the device did not detonate after exposure to extreme forces. In 1980, in Arkansas, a Titan missile in a silo exploded as a result of a liquid fuel leak, which blew the 740 ton silo lid off and catapulted the 2nd stage and warhead into the air. The second stage then blew up and the 9 Megaton warhead was thrown 100 feet away from the entrance to the facility. The designed in safety systems worked and the warhead did not detonate and no radioactive material was released. The forces on the warhead were immense. Sounds pretty safe to me. Titan missiles are no longer active.

Comment: The point of the employment contract is the employer pays you to come to work.  A certain amount of absence due to illness and injury is expected, but when it impacts the ability to get the work done, becomes unreasonably costly, impacts morale of others, etc, the employer has a duty and a right to try and solve the problem.  I worked in disability management for large government and my experience with mental health issues is that many GPs were more enablers than getting the right help.  Often it wasn't until an employee got to long term disability that the appropriate help, often a team, was put in place.  And many times the real issue was an underlying addiction--another area where GPs are sorely lacking in diagnosing and treating.  And if you have stepped forward and asked for assistance and accommodation due to a mental health issue, then an employer must accommodate up to the point of "undue hardship."  You are viewing sick leave as entitlement rather than as part of a contract.

Comment: Will it be okay for your self-driving car to kill you instead of killing others? The automatic braking still could have been too little, too late to have stopped the car. What was the collision angle with the other car? Head on (doubtful) or a glancing blow, so to speak? What was the driver doing with the accelerator? Stomping down on it (more likely given the distance into store and going through some building structure)? If you are serious about preventing future Rylies from suffering this fate, then erecting barriers between parking lots and pedestrian traffic (i.e., the storefront) is going to be more effective from a simple physics perspective. Otherwise, your hopes for a self-driving car - which is actually more limited in what it can do than you apparently think - preventing future victims is naive.

Comment: The initiative does not seem well thought out and never had any input from anyone who knows anything about commercial roofing.  Last October Denver raised the minimum insulation requirement from R-20 to R-30 for re roofing systems.  That small change had an enormous impact on the cost of a replacement roof system, especially if tapered insulation is used.  Now this.  This mandate now increase the cost of a roof from say $10/s.f. to $30 - $200/s.f.  Not to mention ongoing upkeep and the huge water requirements for those systems.  Mandating white membrane roofs would have achieved the same environmental benefit with dramatically reduced costs.  Many studies prove this.  Should have did some homework on this or at least a little research.

Comment: According to the World Health Organization, the infant death rate is the number of infant deaths divided by the total number of live births in a year. Similarly, the WHO definition of neonatal mortality is the number of neonatal deaths divided by the total number of live births in a year. Not surprisingly ALL live born babies, regardless of weight or gestational age are supposed to be included in these calculations. The US adheres to these guidelines, as does Canada. Most other first world countries do not. They cheat by deliberately excluding very premature babies. In other words, they classify the babies who are most likely to die as born dead (and therefore not included) even when they are born alive. 

FAKE NEWS? I don' think so!

Comment: By your very words "Now anyone with literacy (and some money) could find a Bible in their own language", you note that those with money & literacy could read the Bible. 

Prior to the Gutenberg Bible (Latin), only those with a VERY LARGE amount of money, could afford one. That left out the vast majority of people.

 2nd point is that one had to have the ability to read (~ 95% illiteracy), even the vernacular, which allowed a larger number access to the Bible, bit still a minority . If one couldn't afford a personal Bible, one had to go to a religious house, such as a church or monastery, to see a Bible, which were chained down due to their high value. 

In addition, Latin was the language of the literate. Even Newton's, Principia, printed in 1687 was in the language of scholars. Latin. It was finally printed in English some 40+ years later.  

The printing press had a much greater effect then reading in the vernacular, or the Reformation.

...the exact same thing they keep (falsely) accusing the other 97% of scientists off.

There is, of course, a gatekeeping process that is actually keeping most contrarian papers from being published. That process isn't corrupt peer-review or grant-greed or any other conspiracy theory bovine manure however. It's something much more basic: evidence.

Most contrarian papers don't get published because they can't fake evidence convincingly enough.

Comment: For starters, our country loses approximately $100 billion a year in tax revenue as large corporations stash their cash in offshore Swiss bank accounts or other tax havens overseas including setting up shell corporations in the Cayman Islands. Secondly, many of the largest corporations exploit loopholes in the tax code and pay no federal income taxes--so cutting their "taxes" is a joke. Thirdly, the effective tax rate of major corporations which turn a profit is 12.6%--NOT 35%--again cutting their "taxes" is a joke. Finally, giving tax breaks to publicly traded corporations will lead to their stock price increasing, while the government losing out on tax revenue will now be forced to sell treasury bonds which the wealthy will buy which will in turn lead to taxpayers paying them interest on the money they received from the tax breaks. In a nutshell, these tax cuts for large corporations are a vicious cycle making the rich even richer.

Comment: Proportional representation? Nothing proportional about it. Greens with a mere 16% of the popular vote, now wield a power vastly out of proportion to their percentage of votes. 

With proportional representation there will be a plethora of new parties, every party that gets 3%, or 5% or 7% of the vote is entitled to that percentage of the seats in the legislature - and their votes are for sale. Legislative sessions are devoted to deal-making, power-broking & back-stabbing, coalitions made & betrayed. The major parties have to court the favour of the Whacko Party, the Knothead Party & the Just-Plain-Nuts party; all of whom extract commitments that their pet agenda is addressed.  Nothing is accomplished in this environment. Italy: 62 governments in 67 years. Do we want that? 

Weaver thinks he can impose without a referendum. Appalling. If people of BC approve in a referendum, fine.  But no referendum should be a deal-breaker for Liberals & NDP.  Greens have NO power without Libs & NDP.

Comment: The "bundling" is quite different here.  In the U.S. it was a bundle of many different mortgages that were resold as a high-grade investment, even though mort of the mortgages in the bundle were not of very good quality.

The "bundling" discussed in this article is two loans for a single person, one a regular mortgage and the other essentially being an unsecured loan used for the downpayment for the mortgage.

That being said, the underlying issue isn't entirely dissimilar in that you have people who can't really afford the house they are buying, and therefore at a high risk of defaulting, obtaining loans where the details are intentionally obfuscated from lending regulators.

Comment: Human beings are extraordinarily adaptable.  We have learned to live in the most inhospitable places on earth. One of the homeless people I befriended slept for weeks on a plank placed on the bottom shelf of a shopping cart covered with a tarp to keep off the rain.  For months he rejected the hands of help extended to him.  What finally changed his mind and started the process that eventually led to him being housed?  The sweeps.  He got fed up with being made to move.  Indeed all of the people I filmed who left the streets did so only because they were exhausted by the sweeps.  All of them said that if it weren’t for the sweeps they would still be living on the streets.  So how compassionate is it to leave them be?  To paraphrase Hamlet, sometimes you have to be cruel to be kind.

Comment: @Arthur Trevethick:

Something doesn't seem right with what you're saying here.  A family of 4 making only $32K per year would be right around 140% of the federal poverty level.  Assuming that they don't qualify for Medicaid (due to owning a home), they should be able to get Advance Premium Tax Credits to cover most of the cost of their insurance premiums.  At their income level, the ACA stipulates that they must be able to purchase a Silver-level plan through the exchange for roughly 3% of their total income.  Since 3% of $32,000 equals $960 for the year, that would work out to $80/month, once the tax credits are applied.

Are these neighbors buying their insurance on the state exchange?  Is it a Silver-level plan?  Are they applying for and getting the tax credits that they're entitled to?  If the answers to all these questions are Yes, then there's no reason they should be paying $1795/month.  That just doesn't compute.

Comment: You understand that not all 10 carriers are currently at sea, right?

Just because there are 10 carriers we normally only have 2 or 3 actually forward deployed a time. The other carriers are in shipyards doing maintenance that allows them to be forward deployed. These periods are typically 9 months to a year unless they are being refueled. That takes three years. After coming out of the shipyard the ship starts to train to be deployed again. That takes a year. And tragically we just recently saw what happens when a ship fails at it's training with the U.S.S. Fitzgerald.

I understand that some believe that this is money just being thrown away but at the rate our carriers are deployed we really are at the minimum of carriers we need.

My first ship was the U.S.S. Eisenhower CVN 69, the newest Nimitz class at the time. It is 40 years old this year and is slated to retire in 2027. To be replaced by the U.S.S. Enterprise CVN 80.

50 years of service.

Comment: I've rented 4 places from foreign or minority investors.

The bad:
- One landlord forced me to move out when they wanted to sell.
- Two landlords lived overseas and it was slow getting repairs done to the property.
- All landlords were very picky about choosing tenants.
- Some neighboring units were kept vacant to keep them "new" for re-sale later.

The good:
- The rent has been less than a mortgage with a moderate down-payment. (I suspect they paid cash, and rent only needs to cover expenses in holding the property.)
- None were slum-lords, and all cared about maintaining the condition of the property (even if slow).
- Neighboring landlords were also picky about choosing tenants, or just kept units empty, so I had quiet neighbors.

Comment: Exactly.  If it were true that you could hire and retain a woman for only 76% of the cost of her male counterpart, and that a company whose visible diversity vastly outperforms 'conventional' firms, then anyone looking to dominate an industry would build their business to that pattern.

Yet it doesn't happen.

Firms such as Hay Group, Korn-Ferry, Towers etc. specialize in human capital management and have all identified the 'pay gap' as being in the range of 0.6-1% for equivalent roles and experience.  Still something to look at, but not something as sensationalist and patently false as the 76% nonsense.
